## Run dev
1. Install dependencies
```{r, eval = FALSE}
renv::restore(lockfile = 'renv.lock')
```

2. Run the app
```{r, eval = FALSE}
# Set options here
options(golem.app.prod = FALSE) # TRUE = production mode, FALSE = development mode

# Comment this if you don't want the app to be served on a random port
options(shiny.port = httpuv::randomPort())

# Detach all loaded packages and clean your environment
golem::detach_all_attached()
# rm(list=ls(all.names = TRUE))

# Document and reload your package
golem::document_and_reload()

# Run the application
run_app()
```

## Installation

You can install the development version of shinyScenarioEditor from [GitHub](https://github.com/) with:

``` r
# install.packages("devtools")
devtools::install_github("esqLABS/shinyScenarioEditor")
```

## Example

This is a basic example which shows you how to solve a common problem:

```{r example}
library(shinyScenarioEditor)
## basic example code
```

What is special about using `README.Rmd` instead of just `README.md`? You can include R chunks like so:

```{r cars}
summary(cars)
```

You'll still need to render `README.Rmd` regularly, to keep `README.md` up-to-date. `devtools::build_readme()` is handy for this.

You can also embed plots, for example:

```{r pressure, echo = FALSE}
plot(pressure)
```

In that case, don't forget to commit and push the resulting figure files, so they display on GitHub and CRAN.

# Install esqlabs.handsontable
renv::install('esqLABS/esqlabs.handsontable')
